questions.question_text_1: Read the following passage and answer the given subquestions.  In 1923, the year after James Joyce’s novel Ulysses was first published in its complete form, T. S. Eliot wrote: “I hold this book to be the most important expression which the present age has found; it is a book to which we are all indebted, and from which none of us can escape.” Although Ulysses was not yet widely available at the time—its initial print runs were minuscule and it would be banned repeatedly by censorship boards—Eliot was writing in defense of a novel already broadly disparaged as immoral, obscene, formless, and chaotic. His friend Virginia Woolf had described it in her diary as “an illiterate, underbred book … the book of a self-taught working man, & we all know how distressing they are.” In comparison, Eliot’s praise is triumphal. “A book to which we are all indebted, and from which none of us can escape.” And yet this proposed relationship between Ulysses and its readers may not seem altogether inviting either. Do we really want to read a novel in order to experience the sensation of inescapable debt? In the century since its publication, Ulysses has of course become a monument not only of modernist literature but of the novel itself. But it’s also a notoriously “difficult” book. Among all English-language novels, there may be no greater gulf between how much a work is celebrated and discussed, and how seldom it is actually read.  I don’t think it’s a ___________ that very soon after the publication of Ulysses, critics started to speculate that the novel as a form might be dying. In 1925, the Spanish philosopher Jose Ortega y Gasset wrote of the “decline of the novel,” comparing the genre to a “vast but finite quarry.” “When the quarry is worked out,” he warned, “talent, however great, can achieve nothing.” A few years later, in 1930, Walter Benjamin wrote of the “crisis of the novel.” These two very different works, Ortega’s book and Benjamin’s short essay, both make reference, albeit in passing, to James Joyce. In fact, in T. S. Eliot’s piece in praise of Ulysses, he remarks, “If it is not a novel, that is simply because the novel is a form which will no longer serve,” and later adds that “the novel ended with Flaubert and with James.” In the present day, the “death of the novel” is declared so regularly and with so little provocation that this might not seem to be of any great significance: but I don’t know that the novel was ever declared dead even once before Ulysses was published.  Joyce was, as we know, writing at a time of enormous artistic and cultural upheaval. The seemingly stable conventions of classical music were being shattered by composers like Arnold Schönberg; the refined traditions of Western realist painting were revolutionized by the Cubism of Picasso and Braque. And writers like Marcel Proust were already beginning to destabilize the familiarities of the nineteenth-century novel form. It’s easy to understand in this context how a book as innovative and iconoclastic as Ulysses could be seen as striking the final blow against an already ailing literary tradition. In fact, it might be less easy to understand why, one hundred years later, the novel is still lumbering on, not yet superseded by any more popular or critically significant form of textual storytelling. Classical music, after all, effectively gave way to popular music in the twentieth century; figurative painting never again reasserted itself as a dominant cultural form. But novels as we know them are still being written and widely read. And as one of the people writing and reading them, I can’t help but be interested in the question. What exactly did Ulysses do to the novel? And if we can’t escape it, how can we go on?

The seemingly stable conventions of classical music were being shattered by composers like Arnold Schönberg; the refined traditions of Western realist painting were revolutionized by the Cubism of Picasso and Braque. I don’t think it’s a ___________ that very soon after the publication of Ulysses, critics started to speculate that the novel as a form might be dying. In 1925, the Spanish philosopher Jose Ortega y Gasset wrote of the “decline of the novel,” comparing the genre to a “vast but finite quarry.” “When the quarry is worked out,” he warned, “talent, however great, can achieve nothing.” A few years later, in 1930, Walter Benjamin wrote of the “crisis of the novel.” These two very different works, Ortega’s book and Benjamin’s short essay, both make reference, albeit in passing, to James Joyce. In fact, in T. S. Eliot’s piece in praise of Ulysses, he remarks, “If it is not a novel, that is simply because the novel is a form which will no longer serve,” and later adds that “the novel ended with Flaubert and with James.” In the present day, the “death of the novel” is declared so regularly and with so little provocation that this might not seem to be of any great significance: but I don’t know that the novel was ever declared dead even once before Ulysses was published.  Joyce was, as we know, writing at a time of enormous artistic and cultural upheaval. The seemingly stable conventions of classical music were being shattered by composers like Arnold Schönberg; the refined traditions of Western realist painting were revolutionized by the Cubism of Picasso and Braque. And writers like Marcel Proust were already beginning to destabilize the familiarities of the nineteenth-century novel form. It’s easy to understand in this context how a book as innovative and iconoclastic as Ulysses could be seen as striking the final blow against an already ailing literary tradition. In fact, it might be less easy to understand why, one hundred years later, the novel is still lumbering on, not yet superseded by any more popular or critically significant form of textual storytelling. Classical music, after all, effectively gave way to popular music in the twentieth century; figurative painting never again reasserted itself as a dominant cultural form. But novels as we know them are still being written and widely read. And as one of the people writing and reading them, I can’t help but be interested in the question. What exactly did Ulysses do to the novel? And if we can’t escape it, how can we go on?

B: Do you feel that you are exceptionally good at anything in particular?  A: I am good at pulling together teams of people to accomplish a task.  B: What are you not good at?  A: I am impatient with myself at times and am hard on myself.  B: We appreciate hearing that about you!

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, and principles** for the **"Foundation Level: Semester 2: English 2 (Computer-Based Exam)"** based on the provided question paper.
The exam focuses on **reading comprehension, vocabulary, grammar, discourse markers, literary analysis, and communication skills**.

---

---

### **Core Topics & Concepts**
#### **1. Reading Comprehension**
   - **Key Skills**:
     - Identifying main ideas, supporting details, and inferences.
     - Analyzing tone, purpose, and author’s perspective.
     - Understanding contextual vocabulary (e.g., antonyms/synonyms like "indebted" ↔ "unappreciated," "triumphal" ↔ "jubilant").
     - Drawing conclusions from passages (e.g., unique traits of *Ulysses* by James Joyce).
   - **Literary Analysis**:
     - Modernist literature (e.g., *Ulysses* as a "difficult" but monumental work).
     - Themes: Crisis of the novel, cultural upheaval (e.g., Cubism, Schönberg’s music), and artistic innovation.
     - Authorial defense (e.g., T.S. Eliot’s praise vs. Virginia Woolf’s criticism).

#### **2. Vocabulary**
   - **Antonyms/Synonyms**:
     - Example pairs:
       - **Indebted** ↔ Unappreciated
       - **Triumphal** ↔ Jubilant
       - **Upheaval** ↔ Disruption
       - **Innovative** ↔ Unimaginative
       - **Superseding** ↔ Lower
   - **Idioms/Colloquialisms** (from audio-based questions):
     - "Play the fool" = behave comically.
     - "Boob tube" = television set.
     - "Screwed-up" = made a mistake.
     - "Intelligentsia" = highly educated people.
   - **Formal vs. Informal Language**:
     - Polite requests (e.g., "Excuse me, could you tell me your working hours?").
     - Professional communication (e.g., interview dialogue).

#### **3. Grammar**
   - **Tenses**:
     - Present continuous (e.g., "I **am losing** this battle").
     - Conditional sentences (e.g., "If you bend it too hard, it **will break**" = **First Conditional**).
   - **Modals**:
     - Possibility: "The theatre **might/may** be open."
     - Future: "**Will** you finish the book by tomorrow?"
   - **Question Tags**:
     - "Let us take him alive, **shall we**?"
   - **Clauses**:
     - Dependent clauses (e.g., "after she finished her homework" = **adverbial clause**).
     - Relative pronouns (e.g., "the kid **who** lives next door").
   - **Adverbs/Adjectives**:
     - Sentence adverbs (e.g., "**Eventually**, he went inside").
     - Adverbs as adjuncts (e.g., "plays the guitar **beautifully**").
   - **Sentence Types**:
     - Compound-complex: "When cats meow, dogs bark, and birds chirp."
     - Zero/First/Second conditionals.

#### **4. Discourse Markers**
   - Connectors for coherence:
     - **Contrast**: "Even though it is full of gases, it has a diameter of 1.3927 million km."
     - **Addition**: "**Additionally**, it can hold millions of planets."
     - **Result**: "**Consequently**, there would be no life on Earth."
     - **Emphasis**: "**Basically**, all living things get energy from the Sun."
     - **Introduction**: "**As a matter of fact**, the Sun is a huge ball of gases."

#### **5. Figures of Speech**
   - **Simile**: "Cool as a cucumber."
   - **Acronyms**: "NATO" (North Atlantic Treaty Organization).
   - **Word Origins**: "Tsunami" (Japanese origin).

#### **6. Communication Skills**
   - **Formal vs. Informal Contexts**:
     - **Shop scenarios**:
       - Polite: "Could you assist me in locating this item?"
       - Impolite: "Hey, this pan is horrible! Get me a replacement now!"
     - **Interview Dialogue**:
       - Professional tone (e.g., "I am interested in switching fields").
       - Self-awareness (e.g., "I am impatient with myself").
   - **Social Etiquette**:
     - Declining offers politely: "I’m sorry, but I do not want the special offer."
     - Reporting errors: "There are spelling mistakes in your name board."

#### **7. Literary and Cultural References**
   - **James Joyce’s *Ulysses***:
     - Modernist literature’s impact on the novel genre.
     - Criticisms (immoral/chaotic) vs. defenses (Eliot’s praise).
   - **Cultural Movements**:
     - Cubism (Picasso/Braque), Schönberg’s music, Proust’s writing.
   - **Philosophical Views**:
     - Ortega y Gasset’s "decline of the novel," Walter Benjamin’s "crisis of the novel."

---

### **Key Equations/Rules (Grammar-Focused)**
| **Concept**               | **Rule/Example**                                                                 |
|---------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Present Continuous**    | Subject + **am/is/are** + verb-ing (e.g., "I **am losing**").                 |
| **First Conditional**     | **If + present simple**, **will + base verb** (e.g., "If you bend it, it **will break**"). |
| **Question Tags**         | Auxiliary + subject (e.g., "Let’s go, **shall we**?").                        |
| **Relative Clauses**      | **Who/which/that** (e.g., "the kid **who** lives next door").                  |
| **Modals for Possibility**| **May/might** (e.g., "It **might** rain").                                      |
| **Reported Speech**       | Backshift: "Do you like it?" → He **asked if I liked** it.                      |
| **Discourse Markers**     | **Contrast**: Even though / **Addition**: Additionally / **Result**: Consequently. |

---

---
### **Exam Tips**
1. **Reading Passages**:
   - Skim for main ideas first, then scan for details.
   - Pay attention to **tone** (e.g., Eliot’s defense vs. Woolf’s criticism).
2. **Vocabulary**:
   - Memorize antonyms/synonyms for words like "indebted," "innovative," "upheaval."
   - Learn idioms (e.g., "play the fool," "boob tube").
3. **Grammar**:
   - Practice **tenses**, **conditionals**, and **clauses** (identify types in sentences).
   - Use **discourse markers** to structure writing/speaking (e.g., "Additionally," "Consequently").
4. **Communication**:
   - Always choose **polite/formal** options in shop/interview contexts.
   - Avoid aggressive language (e.g., "Get me a replacement now!" → incorrect).
5. **Literary Questions**:
   - Link *Ulysses* to **modernism**, **cultural shifts**, and **criticism of the novel genre**.
